What Language Model Architecture and Pretraining Objective Work Best for Zero-Shot Generalization?
Thomas Wang, Adam Roberts, Daniel Hesslow, Teven Le Scao, Hyung Won Chung, Iz Beltagy, Julien Launay, Colin Raffel
2022
wang2022What

tags: zotero paper-notes
links:

Notes
Goal of the authors is to understand which of the model types and training strategies in the Cambrian explosion of pretrained transformer LMs actually works the best.
To do this they run a large-scale eval across the types in terms of zero-shot generalization performance. Code is provided (github)
I like that they use causal decoder and noncausal decoder Naming the encoder and decoder elements of LMs
Additionally, they discuss Full vs Prefixed vs Masked LM, various fine-tuning tasks, and two eval methods
I like they way they color-coded Cool colorcoding in LM paper the different elements of the paper, where they connect the elements of their diagram to the highlighted colors in the manuscript.
Adaptation Stage was only first introduced last year!
On p3

References/Bias-in-Language-Models_-Beyo.filePath: References/Bias in Language Models_ Beyond Trick Tests and Toward RUTEd Evaluation.md
References/Bias-in-Language-Models_-Beyo.title: Bias in Language Models_ Beyond Trick Tests and Toward RUTEd Evaluation
References/Bias-in-Language-Models_-Beyo.content:
Bias in Language Models: Beyond Trick Tests and Toward RUTEd Evaluation
Kristian Lum, Jacy Reese Anthis, Kevin Robinson, Chirag Nagpal, Alexander D’Amour
2025
In Zotero: lum2025bias
Online: url

tags: research-evaluation research-lm research-bias zotero paper-notes
links:

Notes
RUTE = Realistic Use and Tangible Effects
Bias metrics: neutrality, skew, stereotype
“Standard benchmarks constitute ‘trick tests’: decontextualized evals based on contrived scenarios to elicit a simplified correlation between model output and a sensitive attribute”
They find that bias evals from these contexts are uncorrelated. MEasures don’t generalize to other contexts → same goes for cultural eval. Perspectives don’t transfer to practice
They discuss user persona generation as an evaluation task! cc: Wtf is a persona?!
They use story generation, persona generation, and english learning exercises as tasks.
Metrics:

Neutrality: probabilistic disparity between gendered words by gender
Skew: average tendency to return male instead of female words (ie, not a magnitude as in neutrality)
Stereotype: rate of stereotypical vs antistereotypical word selection

This allows them to show that bias measures are not consistent between tasks.

References/ChatGPT-Doesn`t-Trust-Charger.filePath: References/ChatGPT Doesn`t Trust Chargers Fans_ Guardrail Sensitivity in Context.md
References/ChatGPT-Doesn`t-Trust-Charger.title: ChatGPT Doesn`t Trust Chargers Fans_ Guardrail Sensitivity in Context
References/ChatGPT-Doesn`t-Trust-Charger.content:
ChatGPT Doesn’t Trust Chargers Fans: Guardrail Sensitivity in Context
Victoria R Li, Yida Chen, Naomi Saphra
2024
In Zotero: [liChatGPTDoesntTrust2024](zotero://select/items/@liChatGPTDoesntTrust2024)
Online: url

tags: research-lm research-evaluation zotero paper-notes
links: Discussed wrt

Notes
ChatGPT Doesn’t Trust Chargers Fans from EMNLP 2024
They assess guardrail sensitivity, the overall tendency of the ChatGPT guardrail to refuse requests from some prompt topic across a bunch of different topics and demographic characteristics.
They identify characteristic patterns of how the guardrail “treats” different demographics wrt refusal rate etc. They are able to identify what are effectively “conservative” or “liberal guardrails”.

Key insight: covertly cultural-marking information is carried in these preference cues, which the model is sensitive to. By proxy being a Chargers fan vs a Cowboys fan connotes demographic information including location or background, potential ethnicity, and potential politics.

From the finding that there are different guardrail behaviors under different overt political ideologies, they demonstrate that ChatGPT’s guardrail recovers the expected fanbase conservatism from the team affinity.

References/Cultural-Conditioning-or-Plac.filePath: References/Cultural Conditioning or Placebo_ On the Effectiveness of Socio-Demographic Prompting.md
References/Cultural-Conditioning-or-Plac.title: Cultural Conditioning or Placebo_ On the Effectiveness of Socio-Demographic Prompting
References/Cultural-Conditioning-or-Plac.content:
Cultural Conditioning or Placebo? On the Effectiveness of Socio-Demographic Prompting
Sagnik Mukherjee, Muhammad Farid Adilazuarda, Sunayana Sitaram, Kalika Bali, Alham Fikri Aji, Monojit Choudhury
2024
In Zotero: mukherjeeCulturalConditioningPlacebo2024
Online: url

tags:　#paper-notes research-culture zotero paper-notes
links: Culture as practice drafting

Notes
They condition prompts on “cultural and non-cultural cues” in order to test whether one’s variation is stronger than the others.
(For example, saying one’s favorite programming language vs saying one’s region or age.)
They find that the placebo effect is true---a model is just as likely to vary its response based on this non-conditioned input as it is to vary it according to the targeted one.
They produce placebos based on things like culturally common names, see below

They use datasets that are and aren’t sensitive to culture, going from MMLU and ETHICS to EtiCor, which has region specific etiquette and stuff.
They find that the total rate of variation and modal question-level variation is basically the same for each dataset/datapoint across models in both cue types that can vary: non-cultural and cultural.
This demonstrates that these SIMPLE persona-based prompting techniques (ie., saying the person’s name is Hiroshi vs Bob) for showing cultural sensitivity of LMs are questionable, because it’s just as likely that will perturb the output as saying the person’s favorite programming language is Python.
Important caveat
THAT BEING SAID. Naomi’s students’ ChatGPT Doesn`t Trust Chargers Fans_ Guardrail Sensitivity in Context paper, (also from EMNLP lol) which is centered on Guardrail sensitivity as an example site for this proxy-conditioned output variation to take place.
Taken together these two studies make it difficult to draw a clear line, as they demonstrate that for many seemingly apolitical or non-demographic personas the model is able to effectively recover the likely identity of the persona holder based on indirect information in the preference

References/Investigating-Cultural-Alignm.filePath: References/Investigating Cultural Alignment of Large Language Models.md
References/Investigating-Cultural-Alignm.title: Investigating Cultural Alignment of Large Language Models
References/Investigating-Cultural-Alignm.content:
Investigating Cultural Alignment of Large Language Models
Badr AlKhamissi, Muhammad ElNokrashy, Mai AlKhamissi, Mona Diab
2024
In Zotero: alkhamissiInvestigatingCulturalAlignment2024
Online: url

tags: research-culture research-evaluation research-lm zotero paper-notes
links: Cited by Randomness, Not Representation_ The Unreliability of Evaluating Cultural Alignment in LLMs, relevant to Culture as practice drafting

Notes
Core RQ topics:

Prompting for language and cultural alignment (ask in Arabic to behave in Arabic?)
Adjusting the composition of pretraining data (more training data from community ⇒ better alignmen„t to that community?)
Personas and cultural topics (what do we mean by persona here? (Wtf is a persona?!))
Finetuning Models to Induce Cross-Lingual Knowledge Transfer: they check how well they can FT LLaMA 2 to improve on this

They find the Anglocentric bias in perspectives in LMs, and that mitigations are of limited effectiveness. Some prompting can help.
Relevance to me
What evaluation techniques do they use to try to assess the overall quality of the alignment in these different settings?
Test set: World Values Survey
They select 30 Qs from this US survey that should capture cultural relevance. They check Egypt-US alignment using questions from the survey.
Evaluation paradigm: persona similarity
Here they look for the ability for the LM to answer like an American/Egyptian wrt multiple choice survey questions in a simulated survey.
Metrics:

Hard metric: alignment accuracy (P(model choice = human choice))
Soft metric: error on ordinal options and accuracy on discrete options

Here, the answer to Wtf is a persona?! is output personas, or behavior of the model, applied only to answering demographic surveys.

References/Randomness,-Not-Representatio.filePath: References/Randomness, Not Representation_ The Unreliability of Evaluating Cultural Alignment in LLMs.md
References/Randomness,-Not-Representatio.title: Randomness, Not Representation_ The Unreliability of Evaluating Cultural Alignment in LLMs
References/Randomness,-Not-Representatio.content:
Randomness, Not Representation: The Unreliability of Evaluating Cultural Alignment in LLMs
Ariba Khan, Stephen Casper, Dylan Hadfield-Menell
2025
In Zotero: khanRandomnessNotRepresentation2025
Online: url

tags: paper-notes research-culture research-evaluation zotero paper-notes
links: Culture as practice drafting

Notes
Related work is strong for mining
Cultural alignment in LMs

LLMs tend to reflect values from WEIRD societies (unsurprising , ref The Ghost in the Machine has an American accent_ Value conflict in GPT-3.)

Implication for our work: any understanding issues resulting from this will be passed on to the evaluation.


General bias impact on models, implications for how to evaluate

Evaluating Cultural Alignment

Investigating Cultural Alignment of Large Language Models is very relevant here, (read notes for what it discusses)

Mainly, they use survey responses lol


All of the papers cited in this section have a similar theme: survey questions!

Survey-based assessments

Additional follow ups here
Matching to human surveys is relatively easy.
But there’s limited correlation with human survey responses even when LLMs do indeed reflect these value differences IRL
LLM prefs are sensitive to prompting (shown in the Cultural ALginment paper above)

Setup
They test assumptions of stability, extrapolability, and steerability (defined with results) using this setup:
Alignment to explicit value surveys and implicit values (hiring choices)
They use Hofstedes dimensions of cultural preference:

Power distance index
Individualism vs collectivism
Masculinity vs femininity
Uncertainty avoidance
Long-term/short-term orientation
Indulgence vs restraint

The focus is entirely on these isolated dimensions (the output variability) and not on explicitly labeled cultural defns. This is a strength.
Core assumptions of cultural alignment eval:
Stability

Cultural alignment manifests as a property of LLMs that generally remains consistent across semantic-preserving variations in evaluation methodology, rather than being primarily an artifact of specific prompt design choices.

Doesn’t hold!
Non-semantic changes such as likert scale or context shift the prefs!
Extrapolability

Alignment with one culture on a narrow set of issues generally predicts alignment with that culture on other unobserved issues, such that a limited sample of cultural dimensions is sufficient to characterize an LLM’s overall   cultural alignment.

Within cultural value combos, several dimensions are required to begin to be extrapolable to other dimensions.
This is a property for both humans and LMs, and is probably just an inherently low-information problem.
Steerability

LLMs can be reliably prompted to embody coherent cultural stances that accurately reflect specific human cultural perspectives.

They used the prompting technique from Investigating Cultural Alignment of Large Language Models
Human responses cluster together in their alignment along the axes, while LMs are scattered all over the place.

References/Scaling-Laws-Do-Not-Scale.title: Scaling Laws Do Not Scale
References/Scaling-Laws-Do-Not-Scale.content:
Scaling Laws Do Not Scale
Fernando Diaz, Michael Madaio
2024
In Zotero: diazScalingLawsNot2024
Online: url

tags: research-culture research-evaluation zotero paper-notes
links: Culture as practice drafting

Notes
The paper is a discussion about the limitations of scaling laws wrt cultural values, languages, and sub-groups. Evaluation fails to comprehensively explore this space. The choice of metric to track scaling laws encodes the values of the communities that picked the benchmark itself.
Additionally, they discuss broader issues, such as:

Performance on metrics != model quality
Discuss the use of offline vs online evals, implicit assumption that offline → online, etc
HCI issues, such as “does a metric reflect a real user goal”

They talk about how scaled eval datasets begin to pick up more and more diverse sub-groups who are going to share different values with size. These sub-groups will sometimes have incompatible metrics, here scoped as once again those implicit assumptions and beliefs.
Taken together, this presents a sort of group preference curse of dimensionality that makes answering some questions using larger evaluation sets (without some special and precise lens of pluralism) pointless
Close with quote from Irene Solaiman, Christy Dennison “PALMS”

creating many values-targeted datasets to reflect the cultures of the many peoples impacted by language models is a difficult feat

Which beyond being some limitation, is the fundamental challenge: there are irreconcilable differences between group prefs
My thoughts
I think the paper is actually rather light on examples of these irreconcilable differences. There are examples like the preferences of trolley problem-style questions but it’s unclear to me how those actually relate to a measurable AI capability.
They do have an interesting discussion of this with respect to public opinion surveys. What does it mean for a sample to be representative when there are different categories of

Soft Thinking: Unlocking the Reasoning Potential of LLMs in Continuous Concept Space
Zhen Zhang, Xuehai He, Weixiang Yan, Ao Shen, Chenyang Zhao, Shuohang Wang, Yelong Shen, Xin Eric Wang
2025

tags: zotero paper-notes
links:

Notes

References/The-Case-for-_Thick-Evaluatio.filePath: References/The Case for _Thick Evaluations_ of Cultural Representation in AI.md
References/The-Case-for-_Thick-Evaluatio.title: The Case for _Thick Evaluations_ of Cultural Representation in AI
References/The-Case-for-_Thick-Evaluatio.content:
The Case for “Thick Evaluations” of Cultural Representation in AI
Rida Qadri, Mark Diaz, Ding Wang, Michael Madaio
2025
In Zotero: qadriCaseThickEvaluations2025
Online: url

tags: research-image-generation, research-evaluation, research-culture zotero paper-notes
links: Culture as practice drafting

Notes
What is Thick Evaluation
Defined as “more granular, situated, and discursive” and “steeped in [a community’s own understanding] of representation”
Taken from Gilbert Ryle/Clifford Geertz’s thick vs thin dichotomy (Ryle 1968, The thinking of thoughts… (in my Zotero))
Conflict between SocSci and CS

CS cultural eval: culture is measurable & objective
Social sciences: culture is situated and subjective

Situated: very context-dependent (are we talking about gender? are we talking about geography? are we talking about application use vs a dictionary?), as opposed to:
Abstracted: doesn’t connect to/engage with the community of study. eg., skin tone from western racial categories.


                  
                  TIP
                  
                

Prevailing style of CS (AI in particular) engagement with these topics is important but not complete


How do you do it?
They interviewed participants in South Asia re: culturally situated AI-generated images, finding:

fine-grained multi-dimensional axes that individuals use
empirical data on the categories they use

Interview study w/ annotation task: the annotators themselves are asked to grade the images ostensibly targeting their culture


                  
                  Tip
                  
                

This work targets depth in cultural AI research, pushing the types of questions AI researchers already ask toward


Limitations

Thicknesss is in conflict with generalization and scale (in other words, Scaling Laws Do Not Scale!)

No single correct way to represent the world breaks fundamental assumptions in benchmarking and eval [9,35,80 from the refs]
Goes against positivist assumptions [22,50,58]



Relation to our paper

Situatedness and granularity are also important points in our work
They are focused on pursuing these desiderata toward depth of research in traditionally culture-first CS topics (representativeness of generated images)
We are interested in adding situated-in-culture and culturally-conditioned-granularity as considerations to guide research in non-culture-first research
In other words, we want to extend the breadth of cultural research by bringing these ideas and culturally diverse annotator sampling to non-culture evaluations like general usability of open-ended systems

Perhaps another important theme here is that we’re looking at open-ended tasks rather than culturally-targeted tasks
Connection to the how

Metrics: secondary. The focus is qualitative and in-depth discussions.
Participants themselves were asked to produce the images they checked: this evaluation was directly grounded in user needs (with the one complication being they were explicitly instructed to generate for their culture)
Participants constructed their own rubrics: it’s difficult to prescribe the elements of a representation that users care about. They converged on :

Correctness
Missingness: whether expected cultural elements are missing from the image
Specificity: “generic” and or “stereotypical” things are weighted
Coherence: things like a muslim having alcohol or Chinese lanterns in Tamil festival



![[IMG_The Case for Thick Evaluations of Cultural Representation in AI_039.jpeg]]

References/The-Ghost-in-the-Machine-has-.filePath: References/The Ghost in the Machine has an American accent_ Value conflict in GPT-3..md
References/The-Ghost-in-the-Machine-has-.title: The Ghost in the Machine has an American accent_ Value conflict in GPT-3.
References/The-Ghost-in-the-Machine-has-.content:
The Ghost in the Machine has an American accent: Value conflict in GPT-3.
Rebecca L Johnson, Giada Pistilli, Natalia Menédez-González, Leslye Denisse Dias Duran, Enrico Panai, Julija Kalpokiene, Donald Jay Bertulfo
In Zotero: johnsonGhostMachineHas
Online: url

tags: research-culture research-lm zotero paper-notes
links: Culture as practice drafting

Notes
Another paper discussing the problem of value alignment in LMs.
Here, they demonstrate how the values in an input text conflict with the output values in the generated text, when it conflicts with hegemonic Anglo-US values.
How do they assess values?

Metaphors, such as “tall poppy syndrome”
Relations, like nurse→woman, doctor→man
Dichotomous values like right/wrong good/bad

They feed in input texts from 10 countries and six languages. They ask the models to perform culturally neutral tasks, such as summarization. They use texts that have embedded values, such as activist or political texts.
The evaluation is entirely subjective and expensive. They generate the pseudo-opinions by asking the model to generate an output summary or a summary for a third grader! This is a great example of a reason for Who Cares how LMs answer surveys?: this is a real end-task that aligns with opinions of the fit population.
Result examples
Gun control
Australian public opinion rapidly converged on a preference for strict gun control and buybacks after a single mass shooting. Meanwhile, in the US gun control is an extremely controversial issue due to different cultural attitudes.
Text about the Australian firearms act generated by GPT3 highlighted problems of the loss of liberties and freedom.
de Beauvoir’s The Second Sex
In French, this was described as a “call to rape”
LGBTI pride in Spain
GPT-3 disagreed with a female Spanish minister’s text that LGBTI movement and feminism are aligned due to LGBTI “not focused on equality.” The authors point to higher US distrust toward the women’s movement as evidence for the driver of this behavior.
Laicite
They feed a text about French secularism and GPT3 points out (rightfully) that it is an illiberal principle to restrict overt religious displays in public (based though it may be)
Malcolm X
Apparently GPT3 repeatedly generated text saying “the democrats are the party of the KKK”..l.bruh
Marriage sanctity
In the Philippine Constitution “marriage is sacred” (so divorce is illegal). In the US this passage means “gay marriage should be illegal.” Thus GPT3 parses the Philippine constitutional passage as meaning hte latter rather than the former.
Other points
Embedding bias research relates
They talk about the extensive body of research in approaching text embedding values but move on to look at LLMs instead of behavioral settings.
